conclusion: Analyze the geometry and physics of light refraction and reflection in the optical element.
Square ABCO with side length R, arc AC centered at O with radius R, point source at O.
Light rays emitted uniformly in all directions from point source at O, refractive index n = 2.
For light to exit through AB or BC, it must refract at arc AC and travel directly toward AB or BC.
Critical angle for refraction determined by Snell's law: sin(theta_c) = 1/n = 1/2, theta_c = arcsin(1/2) = 30 degrees.
Light rays incident on arc AC at angles greater than 30 degrees will undergo total internal reflection and cannot exit through AB or BC.
Determine the range of points on arc AC where incident angle exceeds critical angle (30 degrees).
Arc AC spans a quarter-circle, corresponding to an angular range of 90 degrees (from OA to OC).
For incident angle greater than 30 degrees, angle between light ray and radius must exceed 60 degrees.
Light rays emitted from O at angles less than 60 degrees will strike arc AC at incident angles less than 30 degrees, allowing them to refract and exit.
Light rays emitted from O at angles greater than 60 degrees will strike arc AC at incident angles greater than 30 degrees, resulting in total internal reflection.
Angular range of arc where total internal reflection occurs corresponds to light rays emitted at angles between 60 degrees and 90 degrees.
Angular range of total internal reflection is 90 degrees - 60 degrees = 30 degrees.
Total circumference of circle is 2piR, arc AC spans 90 degrees, one-quarter of the circle.
Total length of arc AC is (1/4) * 2piR = piR/2.
Length of arc where total internal reflection occurs is (1/3) * piR/2 = piR/6.
Final answer: Length of arc where light rays undergo total internal reflection is piR/6.
